III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency’s program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Three residents pierced body parts with a paper clip.
Investigation The referral source was the facility, Director. She reported that
the three female residents who are on a pod together pierced their
noses with a paper clip. The girl residents are on a pod together
with no other residents. The residents deny they planned to do
their piercings together or at the same time and date and it was
done without the others being aware.
I interviewed Youth A on 6/5/23 face to face at the facility. She
reported that she re-pierced her belly button with a paper clip that
she obtained from Case Manager P’s office. Youth A reported that
Case manager P was aware she took the paper clip. Youth A
reported that she took the metal nose piece from a face mask that
she found on the ground in the gym and placed it in her belly
button to keep the piercing open. Youth A had the metal in her
belly button for 4-5 days she reported before it was discovered.
Youth A reported she pierced her belly button in her room with the
shade pulled up so nobody could see in her room. Youth A
reported she lied to staff and said she was going to the bathroom
when she was really re-piercing her bellybutton.
I interviewed Youth B face to face at the facility on 6/5/23. She
reported she got 3 paperclips from Case Manager P's office floor.
Youth B indicated Case manager P was sweeping her floor and
her door to her office was open and she and Youth A took 3 paper
clips each off her floor. Youth B reported she placed the paper
clips in her bra to carry it to her room and Case Manager P was
not aware they took the paper clips. Youth B reported when they
went down for shift change about 1:45pm she was in her room
and put her shade up and indicated she was going to the
bathroom. She reported she pierced her nose during that time.
She indicated she sat on the edge of her sink and was able to
pierce her nose with nobody seeing her. Youth B also took a small
2

piece of the metal paper clip and placed it in her nose to keep the
hole open. Youth B reported her nose piercing was not noticed
immediately as she always wears a mask, and it concealed her
nose for a few days. Youth B reported the nurse came down when
the girls’ piercings were discover and looked at them and provided
antibiotic cream for the pierced areas. Youth B reported she did
not know who was on shift the day she pierced her nose.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/5/23.
Youth C reported she is going to be released in a couple days and
she decided to re-pierce her nose as she wanted it open for when
she was out of the facility. Youth C reported she was not aware
the other girls were piercing themselves and she did this in her
room during reflection time which is between 1:45pm and 2:30pm.
Youth C reported they do room checks every 15 minutes during
reflection time and she had her shade up and said she was using
the bathroom. Youth C refused to say how she got a paperclip to
re-pierce her nose but indicated it was not from Youth A or Youth
B and that she got it from a staff member. She would not say who
the staff member was that provided the paper clip. Youth C
reported she cleaned the paperclip and her nose with soap and
water and sanitizer before piercing it. Youth C reported she broke
off a small piece of the paperclip and placed it in her nose to keep
the piercing open. Youth C reported once her piercing was
discovered by staff the nurse looked her over and provided
antibiotic ointment and alcohol wipes. Youth C was not aware of
who was working when she re-pierced her nose.
I interviewed Case manager P on 6/5/23 face to face at the facility.
She reported the girls pierced their body parts over Memorial Day
weekend and she was not working. Case manager P reported the
girls have indicated they got the paperclips on her office floor, and
she was not aware they did this. Case manager P denied ever
giving the youth or being aware of the youth taking paperclips
from her office. Case manager P reported she asked the girls if
they had a pact to do this and they denied having a pact or
knowing what each other was doing. Case Manager P reported
the girls were recently moved from Lincoln Center to Calumet and
she was sweeping her new office floor and the girls stopped by
and talked to her during this time. There were some paperclips on
her floor that she was sweeping up.
I interviewed Youth Worker 1 on 6/16/23 over the phone. She
reported she noticed the resident’s piercings the morning she
opened their doors. Youth Worker 1 reported she told her
supervisor immediately. Youth Worker 1 reported she told the girls
3

they can't put things in their bodies that are not sterile, and they
could get an infection. The girls all refused to take the metal out of
their noses and stomach. Youth A and B reported they got the
paper clips from Case Manager P’s office and Youth C denied to
tell her where she got the item to re-pierce her nose. Youth
Worker 1 reported that Youth C told her she is cool with Youth
Worker 2 and she got the item to re-pierce her nose from Youth
Worker 2 the night before.
I interviewed Youth Worker 2 on 6/16/23 via the phone. Youth
Worker 2 no longer works at the facility. She reported she was at
work the day that the resident’s piercings were discovered. She
reported Youth A showed her the belly button piercing and she
had no idea how Youth A did the piercing. Youth Worker 2
reported she told her supervisor when it was discovered. Youth
Worker 2 denied knowing how the three female residents did their
piercings. She denied ever providing Youth C or any of the youth
with things they could pierce themselves with. Youth Worker 2
reported if she had known the girls were going to do such a thing
or saw them doing it, she would have stopped them.
Youth Worker 3 and Youth Worker 4 were called, and they did not
answer or return the phone call.
Room check logs were reviewed from 5/31/23 during personal
time. The residents were checked on five times between 1:45pm
and 2:33pm when they were in their rooms for personal time.
There is no documentation indicating the youth were observed
piercing their body parts or that they had their shade up or down
during this time.
Analysis Based upon interviews there is no evidence that supports the staff
were not able to provide for the needs, protection and supervision
of the residents. All three-youth admitted to having their shade up
and reporting they were using the bathroom to conceal what they
were doing. There was no way for the staff to know what the girls
were doing while in their rooms. Room checks were being done as
required but the youth had their shades up for privacy and
indicated they were using the restroom.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
